operations_history.operation: Second Battle of El Alamein - initial defense

sources: Asisbiz.com: JG 27 Unit History (Tier 2 - with primary source citations)
Lexikon der Wehrmacht: JG 27 commanders and timeline (Tier 2)
Wikipedia: Jagdgeschwader 27 (unit designation, battle list, operational timeline)
North Africa Air Units Seed File: III./JG 27 WITW ID 103 (Tier 1)
Multiple web sources: JG 27 at El Alamein - serviceability and operations (Tier 2)
metadata.notes: III./JG 27 arrived North Africa from Russia late October 1941. Q4 1942 covers Second El Alamein (October 23-November 11) and final withdrawal from Africa. Commander Ernst D端llberg took command October 11, 1942. Unit achieved 152 air victories in 1942 but suffered 14 pilots killed, 12 captured, 7 wounded, and 72 aircraft lost. By November 1942, JG 27 often had fewer than a dozen fighters serviceable. Gruppe withdrew to Kastelli, Crete on November 12, 1942. Supply situation critical due to extended supply lines and fuel shortages. Aircraft data shows depleted strength at end of North African operations.
metadata.witw_validation: Confirmed in North Africa Air Units Seed File - WITW ID 103

tier_1_2_facts_confirmed: Unit designation 'III./JG 27' confirmed in seed file with WITW ID 103
Aircraft variant Bf 109F-4/Trop documented in multiple Tier 2 sources (Asisbiz, historical records)
Commander Ernst D端llberg took command October 11, 1942 (Lexikon der Wehrmacht - Tier 2)
Bases: Haggag-el-Quasaba (Jul-Sep), Turbiya (Sep-Oct), Tobruk (Nov 2-4), Benghasi (Nov 4-12), Kastelli Crete (Nov 12+) (Asisbiz - Tier 2)
Battle participation at Second El Alamein confirmed in seed file
Withdrawal to Crete November 12, 1942 confirmed (Asisbiz - Tier 2)
By November 1942, JG 27 often had fewer than dozen fighters serviceable (multiple sources - Tier 2)
1942 losses: 14 pilots killed, 12 captured, 7 wounded, 72 aircraft (Lexikon - Tier 2)
source_validation.tier_reasoning: 65% of facts confirmed from Tier 1/2 sources. Seed file confirms unit existence and WITW ID 103. Asisbiz.com provides detailed airfield timeline with primary source citations. Lexikon der Wehrmacht provides commander succession and casualty data. Aircraft variant Bf 109F-4/Trop confirmed in multiple sources. Personnel and detailed ordnance numbers estimated based on standard Gruppe organization (35% estimated). Qualifies for Tier 2 (60-74% Tier 1/2 facts).

corroboration_summary.critical_serviceability: Multiple El Alamein air power sources (Tier 2)

data_quality_notes: Aircraft counts reflect severely depleted state at end of North Africa operations. JG 27 as a whole often had fewer than dozen serviceable fighters by November 1942.
Commander Ernst D端llberg confirmed by Lexikon der Wehrmacht as taking command October 11, 1942, replacing Erhard Braune.
Base locations validated through Asisbiz airfield timeline: unit withdrew through Tobruk (Nov 2-4), Benghasi (Nov 4-12), then to Kastelli, Crete (Nov 12, 1942).
Personnel counts estimated using standard Luftwaffe Gruppe organization (typically 30-40 pilots, 200-250 total), adjusted downward for depleted state.
Ordnance and supply data estimated as 'critical' based on documented fuel shortages and extended supply lines during Axis retreat.
Operations history based on documented Second El Alamein participation and withdrawal timeline from multiple sources.
Only Bf 109F-4/Trop documented for III./JG 27 in Q4 1942. Unit did not receive Bf 109G-2 variants before withdrawal (unlike I./JG 27).
Gruppe achieved 152 air victories in 1942 but suffered heavy losses: 14 pilots killed, 12 captured, 7 wounded, 72 aircraft lost (source: Lexikon der Wehrmacht).
